summary: This is an email exchange between attorney Jeffrey S. Pop and an Assistant U.S. Attorney from the Southern District of New York regarding a female victim's cooperation with the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein. The prosecutor confirms they do not currently believe the victim has criminal exposure related to her interactions with Epstein, and Pop agrees to compile an attorney proffer on her behalf.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pop
persons.context: Attorney communicating with the SDNY about his client, a victim of Jeffrey Epstein, and agreeing to compile an attorney proffer to assist the investigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the SDNY investigation, referenced in relation to the victim's interactions with him.

connections.description: Pop is the attorney representing a female victim in the SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein.
The victim had interactions with Jeffrey Epstein, which are the subject of the SDNY investigation.
Pop is in correspondence with an AUSA from the SDNY regarding his client's cooperation and potential criminal exposure.

events.title: Phone conversation between Pop and AUSA
events.description: A phone conversation occurred between attorney Jeffrey Pop and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the victim's potential criminal exposure in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Pop agrees to compile attorney proffer
events.description: Attorney Jeffrey Pop emails the AUSA agreeing to compile an attorney proffer on behalf of his client to assist the SDNY investigation.

keyFacts: The SDNY investigation into Jeffrey Epstein was active as of December 2019.
An Assistant U.S. Attorney stated they did not currently have reason to believe a specific female victim had criminal exposure based on her interactions with Epstein.
Attorney Jeffrey S. Pop was representing this victim and agreed to compile an attorney proffer to assist the investigation.
The prosecutor suggested any non-federal offenses related to the victim's interactions would likely be outside the statute of limitations.
The correspondence highlights the legal process of securing victim cooperation while assessing potential criminal liability.
